member.summary: An invalid value (-1) as a boolean for some natives (most notably the vehicle param ones) that can skip `true`/`false` parameters.

member.name: F:__OPEN_MP_VERSION
member.remarks: If running on SA:MP this will remain 0, open.mp will set it. open.mp versions look like: 01.04.02.0544 Thus they are encoded here as: (major << 28) | (minor << 21) | (patch << 14) | (prerel)

member.name: F:__SAMP_INCLUDES_VERSION
member.remarks:
Version examples:
0.3.DL R1 - 03D010
0.3.7 R3 - 037030
0.3.7 R2-2 - 037022
0.3.7 R1-2 - 037012
0.3.7 - 037000
0.3z R4 - 030700
0.3z R3 - 030700
0.3z R2-1 - 030700
0.3z R1-2 - 030700
0.3z - 030700
0.3x R2 patch 1 - 030621
0.3x R2 - 030620
0.3x R1-2 - 030612
0.3x - 030600
0.3e - 030500
0.3d - 030400
0.3c - 030300
0.3b - 030200
0.3a - 030100
0.2X - 02A000
0.2.2 R3 - 022300 Rough rules:
Uses (roughtly) BCD. Special versions are denoted outside 0-9. 0.1.2c R4-5 | | || | | 0 1 23 4 5 = 0x012345 (assuming c is the third revision)
0.2X becomes 02A000 because it is basically 0.2.3, but not, while higher than 0.2.2 so can't be 020400 (for example). Also, its a capital letter, so doesn't use the revision method.
P.S. Making a consistent scheme for SA:MP versions is REALLY hard.
open.mp releases can use `A` as the first digit.

member.name: M:@timer
member.summary: A timer event occurred.
member.remarks:
This function executes after the configured delay or interval expires. See settimer to set the delay or interval. Depending on the timing precision of the host, the call may occur later than the delay that was set.
If the timer was set as a "single-shot", it must be ex plicitly set again for a next execution for the @timerfunction. If the timer is set to be repetitive, @timer will continue to be called with the set interval until it is disabled with another call to settimer.
member.returns: The return value of this function is currently ignored.

member.name: M:AddPlayerClass
member.syntax: AddPlayerClass(skin, spawnX, spawnY, spawnZ, angle, weapon1, ammo1, weapon2, ammo2, weapon3, ammo3)
member.param: The skin which the player will spawn with
Float The x coordinate of the spawnpoint of this class
Float The y coordinate of the spawnpoint of this class
Float The z coordinate of the spawnpoint of this class
Float The direction in which the player should face after spawning
t_WEAPON The first spawn-weapon for the player
The amount of ammunition for the primary spawn weapon
t_WEAPON The second spawn-weapon for the player
The amount of ammunition for the second spawn weapon
t_WEAPON The third spawn-weapon for the player
The amount of ammunition for the third spawn weapon
member.summary: Adds a class to class selection. Classes are used so players may spawn with a skin of their choice.

ul.li: The ID of the class which was just added.
319 if the class limit (320) was reached. The highest possible class ID is 319.

member.remarks: The maximum class ID is 319 (starting from 0, so a total of 320 classes). When this limit is reached, any more classes that are added will replace ID 319.

member.name: M:AddStaticVehicle
member.syntax: AddStaticVehicle(modelid, spawnX, spawnY, spawnZ, angle, colour1, colour2)
member.param: The Model ID for the vehicle
Float The x coordinate of the spawnpoint of this vehicle
Float The y coordinate of the spawnpoint of this vehicle
Float The z coordinate of the spawnpoint of this vehicle
Float Direction of vehicle - angle
The primary colour ID. -1 for random (random colour chosen by client)
The secondary colour ID. -1 for random (random colour chosen by client)
member.summary: Adds a 'static' vehicle (models are pre-loaded for players) to the gamemode.

ul.li: The vehicle ID of the vehicle created (between 1 and MAX_VEHICLES).
INVALID_VEHICLE_ID (65535) if vehicle was not created (vehicle limit reached or invalid vehicle model ID passed).

member.remarks: Can only be used when the server first starts (under OnGameModeInit).

member.name: M:ApplyAnimation
member.syntax: ApplyAnimation(playerid, animationLibrary[], animationName[], delta, loop, lockX, lockY, freeze, time, forceSync)
member.param: The ID of the player to apply the animation to
[] The animation library from which to apply an animation
[] The name of the animation to apply, within the specified library
Float The speed to play the animation (use 4.1)
bool If set to 1, the animation will loop. If set to 0, the animation will play once
bool If set to 0, the player is returned to their old x coordinate once the animation is complete (for animations that move the player such as walking). 1 will not return them to their old position
bool Same as above but for the y axis. Should be kept the same as the previous parameter
bool Setting this to 1 will freeze the player at the end of the animation. 0 will not
Timer in milliseconds. For a never-ending loop it should be 0

t_FORCE_SYNC Set to 1 to make server sync the animation with all other players in streaming radius. 2 works same as 1, but will ONLY apply the animation to streamed-in players, but NOT the actual player being animated (useful for npc animations and persistent animations when players are being streamed) (optional=0)
member.summary: Apply an animation to a player.
member.remarks: The optional parameter, which defaults to 0, in most cases is not needed since players sync animations themselves. The parameter can force all players who can see to play the animation regardless of whether the player is performing that animation. This is useful in circumstances where the player can't sync the animation themselves. For example, they may be paused.
An invalid animation library will crash the player's game.
member.returns: This function always returns 1, even if the player specified does not exist, or any of the parameters are invalid (e.g. invalid library).

member.name: M:OnActorStreamIn
member.param: The ID of the actor that has been streamed in for the player
The ID of the player that streamed the actor in
member.summary: This callback is called when an actor is streamed in by a player's client.
member.remarks: This callback can also be called by NPC.
It is always called first in filterscripts.
member.returns: This callback does not handle returns.

member.name: M:OnActorStreamOut
member.param: The ID of the actor that has been streamed out for the player
The ID of the player that streamed the actor out
member.summary: This callback is called when an actor is streamed out by a player's client.
member.remarks: This callback can also be called by NPC.
It is always called first in filterscripts.
member.returns: This callback does not handle returns.

member.name: M:OnClientCheckResponse
member.param: The ID of the player checked
The type of check performed
The address requested
The result of the check
member.summary: This callback is called when a SendClientCheck request comletes

member.name: M:OnDialogResponse
member.param: The ID of the player that responded to the dialog
The ID of the dialog the player responded to, assigned in ShowPlayerDialog
1 for left button and 0 for right button (if only one button shown, always 1)
The ID of the list item selected by the player (starts at 0) (only if using a list style dialog)
[] The text entered into the input box by the player or the selected list item text
member.summary: This callback is called when a player responds to a dialog shown using ShowPlayerDialog by either clicking a button, pressing ENTER/ESC or double-clicking a list item (if using a list style dialog).
member.remarks: A player's dialog doesn't hide when the gamemode restarts, causing the server to print "Warning: PlayerDialogResponse PlayerId: 0 dialog ID doesn't match last sent dialog ID" if a player responded to this dialog after restart.
Parameters can contain different values, based on dialog's style</
member.returns:
Returning 0 in this callback will pass the dialog to another script in case no matching code were found in your gamemode's callback.
It is always called first in filterscripts so returning 1 there blocks other filterscripts from seeing it.

member.name: M:OnEnterExitModShop
member.param: The ID of the player that entered or exited the modshop
1 if the player entered or 0 if they exited
The interior ID of the modshop that the player is entering (or 0 if exiting)
member.summary: This callback is called when a player enters or exits a mod shop.
member.remarks: Players collide when they get into the same mod shop.
member.returns:
This callback does not handle returns.
It is always called first in filterscripts.

member.name: M:OnFilterScriptExit
member.summary: This callback is called when a filterscript is unloaded. It is only called inside the filterscript which is unloaded.
member.returns: This callback does not handle returns.

member.name: M:OnFilterScriptInit
member.summary: This callback is called when a filterscript is initialized (loaded). It is only called inside the filterscript which is starting.
member.returns: This callback does not handle returns.

member.name: M:OnGameModeExit
member.summary: This callback is called when a gamemode ends, either through 'gmx', the server being shut down, or GameModeExit.
member.remarks: This function can also be used in a filterscript to detect if the gamemode changes with RCON commands like changemode or gmx, as changing the gamemode does not reload a filterscript.

When using OnGameModeExit in conjunction with the 'rcon gmx' console command keep in mind there is a potential for client bugs to occur an example of this is excessive RemoveBuildingForPlayer calls during OnGameModeInit which could result in a client crash.
This callback will NOT be called if the server crashes or the process is killed by other means, such as using the Linux kill command or pressing the close-button on the Windows console.
member.returns:
0 - Will prevent other filterscripts from receiving this callback.
1 - Indicates that this callback will be passed to the next filterscript.
It is always called first in gamemode.

member.name: M:OnGameModeInit
member.summary: This callback is triggered when the gamemode starts.
member.remarks: This function can also be used in a filterscript to detect if the gamemode changes with RCON commands like changemode or gmx, as changing the gamemode does not reload a filterscript.
member.returns:
0 - Will prevent other filterscripts from receiving this callback.
1 - Indicates that this callback will be passed to the next filterscript.
It is always called first in gamemode.

member.name: M:OnIncomingConnection
member.param: The ID of the player attempting to connect
[] The IP address of the player attempting to connect
The port of the attempted connection
member.summary: This callback is called when an IP address attempts a connection to the server. To block incoming connections, use BlockIpAddress.
member.returns:
1 - Will prevent other filterscripts from receiving this callback.
0 - Indicates that this callback will be passed to the next filterscript.
It is always called first in filterscripts.

member.name: M:OnObjectMoved
member.param: The ID of the object that was moved
member.summary: This callback is called when an object is moved after MoveObject (when it stops moving).
member.remarks: SetObjectPos does not work when used in this callback. To fix it, recreate the object.
member.returns:
This callback does not handle returns.
It is always called first in filterscripts.

member.name: M:OnPickupStreamIn
member.param: The ID of the pickup, returned by CreatePickup
The ID of the player that picked up the pickup
member.summary: Called when a pickup enters the visual range of a player.
member.returns:
This callback does not handle returns.
It is always called first in gamemode.

member.name: M:OnPickupStreamOut
member.param: The ID of the pickup, returned by CreatePickup
The ID of the player that picked up the pickup
member.summary: Called when a pickup leaves the visual range of a player.
member.returns:
This callback does not handle returns.
It is always called first in gamemode.

member.name: M:OnPlayerClickMap
member.param: The ID of the player that placed a target/waypoint
Float The X float coordinate where the player clicked
Float The Y float coordinate where the player clicked
Float The Z float coordinate where the player clicked (inaccurate - see note below)
member.summary: OnPlayerClickMap is called when a player places a target/waypoint on the pause menu map (by right-clicking).
member.remarks: The Z value returned will be 0 (invalid) if it is far away from the player; use the MapAndreas plugin to get a more accurate Z coordinate.
member.returns:
1 - Will prevent other filterscripts from receiving this callback.
0 - Indicates that this callback will be passed to the next filterscript.
It is always called first in gamemode.

member.name: M:OnPlayerClickPlayer
member.param: The ID of the player that clicked on a player on the scoreboard
The ID of the player that was clicked on
t_CLICK_SOURCE The source of the player's click
member.summary: Called when a player double-clicks on a player on the scoreboard.
member.remarks: There is currently only one (0 - CLICK_SOURCE_SCOREBOARD). The existence of this argument suggests that more sources may be supported in the future.
member.returns:
1 - Will prevent other filterscripts from receiving this callback.
0 - Indicates that this callback will be passed to the next filterscript.
It is always called first in filterscripts.

member.name: M:OnPlayerClickPlayerTextDraw
member.param: The ID of the player that selected a textdraw
PlayerText The ID of the player-textdraw that the player selected
member.summary: This callback is called when a player clicks on a player-textdraw. It is not called when player cancels the select mode (ESC) - however, OnPlayerClickTextDraw is.
member.remarks: When a player presses ESC to cancel selecting a textdraw, OnPlayerClickTextDraw is called with a textdraw ID of INVALID_TEXT_DRAW. OnPlayerClickPlayerTextDraw won't be called also.
member.returns:
Returning 1 in this callback will prevent it being called in other scripts. This should be used to signal that the textdraw on which they clicked was 'found' and no further processing is needed. You should return 0 if the textdraw on which they clicked wasn't found, just like in OnPlayerCommandText.
It is always called first in filterscripts so returning 1 there also blocks other scripts from seeing it.

member.name: M:OnPlayerClickTextDraw
member.param: The ID of the player that clicked on the textdraw
Text The ID of the clicked textdraw. INVALID_TEXT_DRAW if selection was cancelled
member.summary: This callback is called when a player clicks on a textdraw or cancels the select mode with the Escape key.
member.remarks: The clickable area is defined by TextDrawTextSize. The x and y parameters passed to that function must not be zero or negative.
Do not use CancelSelectTextDraw unconditionally within this callback. This results in an infinite loop.
member.returns:
Returning 1 in this callback will prevent it being called in other scripts. This should be used to signal that the textdraw on which they clicked was 'found' and no further processing is needed. You should return 0 if the textdraw on which they clicked wasn't found, just like in OnPlayerCommandText.
It is always called first in filterscripts so returning 1 there also blocks other scripts from seeing it.

member.name: M:OnPlayerCommandText
member.param: The ID of the player that entered a command
[] The command that was entered (including the forward slash)
member.summary: This callback is called when a player enters a command into the client chat window. Commands are anything that start with a forward slash, e.g. /help.
member.remarks: This callback can also be called by NPC.
member.returns:
Return 1 if the command was processed, otherwise 0; If the command was not found both in filterscripts and in gamemode, the player will be received a message: SERVER: Unknown command.
It is always called first in filterscripts so returning 1 there blocks other scripts from seeing it.

member.name: M:OnPlayerConnect
member.param: The ID of the player that connected
member.summary: This callback is called when a player connects to the server.
member.remarks: This callback can also be called by NPC.
member.returns:
0 - Will prevent other filterscripts from receiving this callback.
1 - Indicates that this callback will be passed to the next filterscript.
It is always called first in filterscripts.

member.name: M:OnPlayerDeath
member.param: The ID of the player that died
The ID of the player that killed the player who died, or INVALID_PLAYER_ID if there was none
The ID of the reason for the player's death
member.summary: This callback is called when a player dies, either by suicide or by being killed by another player.
member.remarks:
The reason will return 37 (flame thrower) from any fire sources (e.g. molotov, 18)
The reason will return 51 from any weapon that creates an explosion (e.g. RPG, grenade)
You do not need to check whether killerid is valid before using it in SendDeathMessage. INVALID_PLAYER_ID is a valid killerid ID parameter in that function.
playerid is the only one who can call the callback. (good to know for anti fake death)
member.returns:
0 - Will prevent other filterscripts from receiving this callback.
1 - Indicates that this callback will be passed to the next filterscript.
It is always called first in filterscripts.

member.name: M:OnPlayerDisconnect
member.param: The ID of the player that disconnected
The reason for the disconnection. See table below
member.summary: This callback is called when a player disconnects from the server.
member.remarks: This callback can also be called by NPC.

Some functions might not work correctly when used in this callback because the player is already disconnected when the callback is called. This means that you can't get unambiguous information from functions like GetPlayerIp and GetPlayerPos.

ul.li: 0 - timeout/Crash - the player's connection was lost. Either their game crashed or their network had a fault.
1 - quit - the player purposefully quit, either using the /quit (/q) command or via the pause menu.
2 - kick/ban - the player was kicked or banned by the server.

member.returns:
0 - Will prevent other filterscripts from receiving this callback.
1 - Indicates that this callback will be passed to the next filterscript.
It is always called first in filterscripts.

member.name: M:OnPlayerGiveDamage
member.param: The ID of the player that gave damage
The ID of the player that received damage
Float The amount of health/armour damagedid has lost (combined)
The reason that caused the damage
The body part that was hit. (NOTE: This parameter was added in 0.3z. Leave it out if using an older version!)
member.summary: This callback is called when a player gives damage to another player.
member.remarks:
Keep in mind this function can be inaccurate in some cases.
If you want to prevent certain players from damaging eachother, use SetPlayerTeam.
The weaponid will return 37 (flame thrower) from any fire sources (e.g. molotov, 18)
The weaponid will return 51 from any weapon that creates an explosion (e.g. RPG, grenade)
playerid is the only one who can call the callback.
The amount is always the maximum damage the weaponid can do, even when the health left is less than that maximum damage. So when a player has 100.0 health and gets shot with a Desert Eagle which has a damage value of 46.2, it takes 3 shots to kill that player. All 3 shots will show an amount of 46.2, even though when the last shot hits, the player only has 7.6 health left.
member.returns:
1 - Callback will not be called in other filterscripts.
0 - Allows this callback to be called in other filterscripts.
It is always called first in filterscripts so returning 1 there blocks other filterscripts from seeing it.

member.name: M:OnPlayerUpdate
member.param: ID of the player sending an update packet
member.summary: This callback is called every time a client/player updates the server with their status. It is often used to create custom callbacks for client updates that aren't actively tracked by the server, such as health or armor updates or players switching weapons.
member.remarks: This callback can also be called by NPC.
This callback is called, on average, 30 times per second, per player; only use it when you know what it's meant for (or more importantly what it's NOT meant for).
The frequency with which this callback is called for each player varies, depending on what the player is doing. Driving or shooting will trigger a lot more updates than idling.
member.returns:
0 - Update from this player will not be replicated to other clients.
1 - Indicates that this update can be processed normally and sent to other players.
It is always called first in filterscripts.

member.name: M:OnPlayerWeaponShot
member.syntax: OnPlayerWeaponShot(playerid, weaponid, hittype, hitid, fX, fY, fZ)
member.param: The ID of the player that shot a weapon
The ID of the weapon shot by the player
t_BULLET_HIT_TYPE The type of thing the shot hit (none, player, vehicle, or (player)object)
The ID of the player, vehicle or object that was hit
Float The X coordinate that the shot hit
Float The Y coordinate that the shot hit
Float The Z coordinate that the shot hit
member.summary: This callback is called when a player fires a shot from a weapon. Only bullet weapons are supported. Only passenger drive-by is supported (not driver drive-by, and not sea sparrow / hunter shots).
member.remarks: BULLET_HIT_TYPE_PLAYER is also called for NPCs. Actors are ignored by this callback and detects as BULLET_HIT_TYPE_NONE.
This callback is only called when lag compensation is enabled.

Isn't called if you fired in vehicle as driver or if you are looking behind with the aim enabled (shooting in air).
It is called as BULLET_HIT_TYPE_VEHICLE with the correct hitid (the hit player's vehicleid) if you are shooting a player which is in a vehicle. It won't be called as BULLET_HIT_TYPE_PLAYER at all.
GetPlayerLastShotVectors can be used in this callback for more detailed bullet vector information.
member.returns:
0 - Prevent the bullet from causing damage.
1 - Allow the bullet to cause damage.
It is always called first in filterscripts so returning 0 there also blocks other scripts from seeing it.

member.name: M:OnRconCommand
member.param: [] A string containing the command that was typed, as well as any passed parameters
member.summary: This callback is called when a command is sent through the server console, remote RCON, or via the in-game "/rcon command".
member.remarks: You will need to include this callback in a loaded filterscript for it to work in the gamemode!
"/rcon" is not included in "cmd" when a player types a command.
If you use the print function here, it will send a message to the player who typed the command in-game as well as the log.
This callback is not called when the player is not logged in as RCON admin.

When the player is not logged in as RCON admin and uses /rcon login, this callback will not be called and OnRconLoginAttempt is called instead. However, when the player is logged in as RCON admin, the use of this command will call this callback.
member.returns:
0 if the command was not processed, it will be passed to another script or 1 if the command was processed, will not be passed to other scripts.
It is always called first in filterscripts so returning 1 there blocks gamemode from seeing it.

member.summary: This callback is called when someone attempts to log in to RCON in-game; successful or not.
member.remarks: This callback is only called when /rcon login is used in-game.
This callback is only called when the player is not yet logged in. When the player is logged in, OnRconCommand is called instead.

member.name: M:cvttimestamp
member.param: & This will hold the year upon return.
& This will hold the month (1-12) upon return.
& This will hold the day of (1-31) the month upon return.
& This will hold the hour (0-23) upon return.
& This will hold the minute (0-59) upon return.
& This will hold the second (0-59) upon return.
member.summary: Convert a time-stamp into a date and time.
member.remarks: Some file and system functions return time-stamps as the number of seconds since midnight, 1 January 1970, which is the start of the UNIX system epoch. This function allows to convert these time stamps into date and time fields. cvttimestamp = ConVerT TIMESTAMP.
member.returns: This function always returns 0.

member.name: M:delay
member.param: The delay, in milliseconds.
member.summary: Halts execution a number of milliseconds.
member.remarks: On some platforms, the sleep instruction also delays for a given number of milliseconds. The difference between the sleep instruction and the delay function is that the delay function does not yield events and the sleep instruction typically yields. When yielding events, any pending events are handled. As a result, the delay function waits without handling any pending events and the sleep instruction waits and deals with events.
member.returns: This function always returns 0.

member.summary: Returns the free disk space.
member.remarks: The maximum size that can be supported 2048 GiB (2 terabyte).
member.returns: The amount of free space in KiB.

member.name: M:getchar
member.param: bool If true, the character read from the keyboard is echoed on the display.
member.summary: Read one character.
member.return: The numeric code for the character that is read (this is usually the ASCII code).

member.name: M:getstring
member.summary: Read a line.
member.return: The number of characters read, excluding the terminating null character.
member.remarks: Function getstring stops reading when either the enter key is typed or the maximum length is reached. The maximum length is in cells (not characters) and it includes a terminating null character. The function can read both packed and unpacked strings; when reading a packed string, the function may read more characters than the size parameter specifies, since each cell holds multiple characters.

member.name: M:getvalue
member.param: Must be between 2 and 36, use 10 for decimal or 16 for hexadecimal.
The character code that terminates the input. More than one character may be listed.
member.summary: Read a number.
member.remarks: Read a value (a signed number) from the keyboard. The getvalue function allows you to read in a numeric radix from 2 to 36 (the base parameter) with decimal radix by default. By default the input ends when the user types the enter key, but one or more different keys may be selected (the end parameter and subsequent). In the list of terminating keys, a positive number (like '\r') displays the key and terminates input, and a negative number terminates input without displaying the terminating key.

member.summary: Set cursor location.
member.return: true if the cursor moved and false if the requested position is invalid.
member.remarks: Sets the cursor position on the console. The upper left corner is at (1,1).

member.name: M:print
member.param: [] The string to print
The string to print

Colour codes for the foreground and the background of the text string; see function setattr for a list of colours. When left at -1, the default colours are used. Note that a terminal or a host application may not support colours.
member.summary: Prints a string to the server console (not in-game chat) and logs (server_log.txt).

member.name: M:printf
member.param: [] The format string
{Float,_} Indefinite number of arguments of any tag
member.summary: Outputs a formatted string on the console (the server window, not the in-game chat).
member.remarks: The format string or its output should not exceed 1024 characters. Anything beyond that length can lead to a server to crash.
This function doesn't support packed strings.

ul.li: %i - integer (whole number)
%d - integer (whole number).
%s - string
%f - floating-point number (Float: tag)
%c - ASCII character
%x - hexadecimal number
%b - binary number
%% - literal %
%q - escape a text for SQLite. (Added in 0.3.7 R2)

member.remarks: The values for the placeholders follow in the exact same order as parameters in the call. For example, "I am %i years old" - the %i will be replaced with an Integer variable, which is the person's age.

You may optionally put a number between the % and the letter of the placeholder code. This number indicates the field width; if the size of the parameter to print at the position of the placeholder is smaller than the field width, the field is expanded with spaces. To cut the number of decimal places beeing shown of a float, you can add .<max number> between the % and the f. (example: %.2f)

member.name: M:setattr
member.param: The string to print

Colour codes for the foreground and the background of the text string; see function setattr for a list of colours. When left at -1, the default colours are used. Note that a terminal or a host application may not support colours
member.summary: Set text colours.
member.remarks: On most systems, the colour value must be a value between zero and seven, as per the ANSI escape sequences, ISO 6429. Predefined constants for the colours are black (0), red (1), green (2), yellow (3), blue (4), magenta (5), cyan (6), and white (7).

member.name: M:setdate
member.param: The year to set; if set to "cellmin", the default value, it is ignored.
The month to set; if set to "cellmin", the default value, it is ignored.
The day to set; if set to "cellmin", the default value, it is ignored.
member.summary: Set the system date.
member.returns: This function always returns 0.
member.remarks: The date fields are kept in a valid range. For example, when setting the month to 13, it wraps back to 1 - this is always wrapped to the min/max, not modulo.

member.name: M:settime

The second to set, in the range 0-59; if set to "cellmin", the default value, it is ignored.
member.summary: Set the system time.
member.returns: This function always returns 0.
member.remarks: The time fields are kept in a valid range. For example, when setting the hour to 24, it wraps back to 0 - this is always wrapped to the min/max, not modulo.

member.summary: Compares two strings to see if they are the same.

If you compare strings from a text file, you should take in to account the 'carriage return' and 'new line' special characters (\r \n), as they are included, when using fread.

1 or -1 if some character do not match: string1[i] - string2[i].
difference in number of characters if one string matches only part of another string.
